4 And whereas we have heretofore rec
o
mended unto the said States generall
Corronell Shinck
and divers others (of both whose names and causes ye
shall receave particular information from our Secreatarie) who as wee
are enformed in steed of favo
r
have receaved from them verie hard measure,
wherby

whereby they doe lay open unto the world their owne ingratitude towards us,
to no small touch of our hono
r
, to see us had in a kind of contempt by those that
are so infinitely bound unto us as they are, a matter so publickly knowen, as
it needeth no debating: Our pleasure therfore is that you shall deale most
earnestly with them in moving them to yeald us better contentment hereafter
in this behalf then heretofore they have done, aswell for their owne creditt, w
ch
receaveth no small blemish by this unkind maner of dealing of theirs towards
us, as also for our hono
r
who may in no sort endure to suffer such as have
been and are noted to stand well affected towards us, so injuriously handled
as they are, espetially the parties by us recomended, having been men of best
desert, and such of whose service they have most need, namely, Coronell Shinck
being for valour, courage and conduct (accompanied besides with an ex-
traordinarie good fortune) one of the rare men of this our age. And to the
end the reparation that wee require in this behalf may not bee delaied w
th
some aunsweare in generall termes: wee thinck yt convenient that you should
urge them to yeald their particular aunsweare to such requests as have been
heretofore rec
o
mended by us.
5 Amongest other thinges fytt to be remembred unto them, you shall lett them
understand that wee, hearing that
e States generall doe oft times dissolve,
and that the Counsell of Estate have their authoritie so restreyned as they
cannot upon such extraordinarie events as fall out in these Contries, full
of perill and daunger, and require speedie resolution, yeld that timely re-
medie that were expedient, doe thincke yt most convenient (thenemie being
so strong as he is in the field) that you doe advise them in o
r
name to conti-
nue their assemblies, or els to enlarge the authoritie of the Councell of Estate.
But before you deale herein wee would have you particularly enforme yo
r
self both by our servant Henrie Killegrewe and others of the Councell of
Estate

Estate that you shall learne by him to bee men of best judgement and best
affected to the good of those Contries, what were fitt in particulareties to be
urged in our name in that behalf, to thend you may proceed therein with
the better effect.

re

e

unto us, as from our servant Henrie Killegrewe that the
last Instructions given by the States generall to
e Counsell of Estate,

ch

docto
r

o
n

most earnestly for the speedie reformation and redresse thereof in such sort
as
e Contract passed between us and them bee not anie way abridged
or infringed by them.
7 And for that wee find that by reason of the licenses graunted by the States
and by other meanes underhand used by the
king of Spaines
ministers,
the said king and his Armados have heretofore been furnished from thence
of great stoare both of Cordage, graine, and sondrie other provisions,
without the w
ch
he had never been able to sett forth to the seas so huge an
armie, and so well stoared with all kind of necessaries, which (as since
yt hath been proved) he minded to have employed against this o
r
Realm,
had not god of his great goodnes broken his ambitious desseigne so as
yf he may nowe bee kept from drawing like provisions out of those Con-
tries and other Contries (for the stay whereof wee have taken some order)
he shall not in manie yeares been able to drawe together so great forces
of that strength as those were the last yeare. You shall therfore deale
most effectually with the said States to inhibite the transportation of
anie like c
o
modities into
Spaine
, the same to be ordeyned with great
penalties and with severe punishment against the offendors: adding ther-
to that yf anie such provisions shalbe found in anie shipp eyther of those
Contries or of anie other, that shall come within the power of anie of our
owne shippes or into anie of our ports, we will take
e same shippes con-
fiscate, as ayders of our open enemies.
8 Being enformed that neyther the States generall nor
e
Counsell of
warre
in those Contries doe acquaint the L. Willoughbye with such
resoluc
o
ns

resolucions as they take in martyall affayres nor with the disposing of
their forces for the withstanding of thenemie wee thinck yt therfore verie
convenient that you should at your arrival there enforme your selfe
thoroughly at the L. Willoughbies hands, howe and in what sort they
doe carie them selves towards him aswell in imparting unto him their
roceeding in martiall causes as also with
e matters of pollecie ten-
ding to
e good government of those Contries: And in case upon confe-
rence with him you shall find that they doe not make him acquainted
with their proceeding in matters of government as well in martiall
causes as otherwise, in such ample sort as was agreed on in
e Contract
that passed between us and those Contries: then our pleasure is that
you shall take some particular notes from him wherein they fayle
to observe
e said contract, to thend you may in our name charge the
said States Generall therewithall, and require of them better obser-
vation thereof in time to come, and that o
r
Generall the L. Willoughby
bee from time to time made acquainted with their Martiall affayres
and to bee present at
e debating of the same, to thend he may both give
his advice and assent to such thinges as he shall find meet for the
good of those Contries to bee put in execution.
9 And whereas wee have been enformed that
e L. Willoughbie hath both at
florilegium
sondrie times past and shall dayly have occasion to disburse good so
m
es of
money for the enterteyning of intelligences out of thenemies Contrie to
e
end to bee enformed of his proceedings, a matter verie necessarie and be-
hovefull for
e guyding and administring of manie matters of great
importance tending aswell to
e annoyance of the'nemie, as for the a-
voyding of some daungerous attempts against the said Contries, and
for the which
e States Generall did yeald an allowance to our
Late Cousen
e
Erle of Leycester
in the time of his government, by an
increase of his monethly enterteinement for
t
purpose: Our plea-
sure is that you should move
e States to make also some competent
allowance to
e said L. Willoughbie for
e said matter of intelligence,
as in reason they ought, and not to expect that the same should be allowed
by us, considering that it is no way employed to our behoufe but only
for
e service and good of those Contries. And wee thinck yt also
meet that upon some just occasion to be taken by you at your discretion,
you should lett them understand as by way of your owne opinion, but
not so directed by us, that you thinck wee could like well
t

should

vice, and by way of thankfulnes towards a nobleman, consuming

10 And whereas some overture hath heretofore been made unto us by
M
r

upon direction receaved from some of the States Generall who
carrie greatest sway among them, that wee would bee pleased for
t

e said offer
